title: 2 Fast and Easy Ways to Convert HTML to a Word Document

steps.title: Convert your HTML file to plain text if necessary.
steps.content: Convert your HTML file to plain text if necessary. If you saved your HTML file as an RTF (rich text format) file—especially if you copied it from the internet—it may have retained some of its formatting; if so, Word may not format the page for you when you open the HTML file. You can ensure that your HTML file uses plain text format by doing the following: Open Notepad by typing notepad into Start and then clicking Notepad . Paste your copied HTML into Notepad by pressing Ctrl + V . Click File . Click Save As... . Click the "Save as type" drop-down box. Click All Files . Type a file name followed by .html into the "File name" text box. Click Save .

steps.title: Open Microsoft Word.
steps.content: Open Microsoft Word. Click or double-click the Word app icon, which resembles a white "W" on a dark-blue background. This will open the Microsoft Word launch page.

steps.title: Click Open.
steps.content: Click Open . It's a link on the left side of the window with an icon of an open folder.

steps.title: Select your document and click Open.
steps.content: Select your document and click Open . It's in the bottom-right corner of the window. This will open the HTML document in its formatted form in Microsoft Word. If you're using Word 365, you need to click Browse first. You can also double-click the file to open it without clicking Open .

steps.title: Make any necessary changes.
steps.content: Make any necessary changes. While Word should format your document exactly as it appears on the web page, you may need to clean up the formatting by ensuring that headings are bolded, images are centered, and so on.

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . It's on the top-left side of the Word window.

steps.title: Click Save As.
steps.content: Click Save As . You'll find this option on the left side of the window.

steps.title: Double-click This PC.
steps.content: Double-click This PC . It's in the middle of the page. Doing so prompts a pop-up window to appear.

steps.title: Save it as a Word document.
steps.content: Save it as a Word document. Click the Save as file type drop-down menu and select Word Document . You can also enter a new name for your Word file in the "File name" text box if need be. You can also choose a new save location (e.g., the Desktop) by clicking a folder in the left-hand sidebar.

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save . This option is in the bottom-right corner of the window. Doing so will save a Word copy of your HTML file. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Convert your HTML file to plain text if necessary.
steps.content: Convert your HTML file to plain text if necessary. If you saved your HTML file as an RTF (rich text format) file—especially if you copied it from the Internet—it may have retained some of its formatting; if so, your Mac's Microsoft Word won't convert it into a document. You can remove formatting by doing the following: Open TextEdit by typing textedit into Spotlight and then double-clicking TextEdit . Click New Document when prompted. Click File . Click Make Plain Text . Paste in your HTML file's text. Press ⌘ Command + S . Select Web Page from the "File Format" drop-down box. Click Save .

steps.title: Open Microsoft Word.
steps.content: Open Microsoft Word. Click or double-click the Word app icon, which resembles a white "W" on a dark-blue background.

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . It's a menu item in the upper-left side of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Open….
steps.content: Click Open… . This is in the drop-down menu. Doing so opens a Finder window.

steps.title: Select your HTML document.
steps.content: Select your HTML document. Go to the location where your HTML document is stored, then click it once.

steps.title: Click Open.
steps.content: Click Open . It's a blue button in the bottom-right corner of the window.

steps.title: Make any necessary changes.
steps.content: Make any necessary changes. While Word should format your document exactly as it appears on the web page, you may need to clean up the formatting by ensuring that headings are bolded, images are centered, and so on.

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . It's in the top-left corner of the screen. This prompts a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Save As….
steps.content: Click Save As… . This option is in the drop-down menu. Doing so opens the Save As window.

steps.title: Save the file as a Word document.
steps.content: Save the file as a Word document. Click the "File Format" drop-down menu and select "Word document". You can also change the name of the file by typing a new name into the "Name" text box, or select a new save location by clicking a folder on the left side of the window.

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save . It's at the bottom of the window. Doing so will create a Word copy of your HTML document.

steps.title: Upload your HTML and download your .DOCX file.
steps.content: Upload your HTML and download your .DOCX file. Searching online will provide many different services to convert your HTML document to Word. But make sure this service is offered for free! Some services will offer a smaller amount of converted pages for free, which may or may not work for you. Some online converters include Wizlogo and Wordize .
